title-group.article-title: Multi-scale simulations of fire growth on a sandwich composite structure

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratoire national de métrologie et d’essais (LNE), Trappes, France

author-notes.corresp: Damien M Marquis, Laboratoire national de métrologie et d’essais (LNE), 29 Avenue Roger Hennequin 78197, Trappes, France. Email: damien.marquis@lne.fr

abstract.p: A coupled pyrolysis/computational fluid dynamics model is used to investigate the fire contribution of glass fibre–reinforced polyester/balsa-cored sandwich composite structure in case of fire on board a ship. Prior to simulating real-scale scenarios, numerical simulations of experiments were performed on samples of the tested material of increasing size, for validation and evaluation purposes. The main idea was to assess gradually the ability of the model to reproduce the fire growth on our composite material faithfully. The numerical and experimental results are compared and discussed. Overall, the numerical results are in good agreement with the experimental data, encouraging simulations at real scale.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer-based composite materials offer many advantages over traditional steel for structural application in shipbuilding. However, unlike other materials such as steel and aluminium, current composite materials commonly used in structure are reactive. They decompose and release heat and smoke when exposed to high temperatures during fires. This characteristic is one of the most significant factors limiting the use of composites in structure. Regulatory bodies require that the divisions of large ships are made of non-combustible material (steel or equivalent material and non-combustible insulations). For these reasons, the fire performance of composite structures is a major issue to use such materials for marine applications. Since 2002, the International Convention for Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) of the International Maritime Organization (IMO)1 has made it possible to use combustible materials for shipbuilding (SOLAS Ch. II-2 – Rule 17), as it is demonstrated that required fire safety performance objectives are still met.2 In this context, the Fire Safety Engineering (FSE) methodology worked out in the French collaborative research project, EMC2 MP08 ‘Fire performance of composites for shipbuilding’,3 sets up a reference frame to that end. This methodology was applied to make sure that fibre-reinforced polyester/balsa-cored sandwich composite could be used in shipbuilding. It used numerical simulations to study the contribution of the studied composite material itself to fire on board ships in various scenarios.

Until recently, the conventional approach to evaluate the fire response of composite consists of performing fire test at real scale on selected components of the considered whole structure. These tests can offer a lot of information about the structure integrity of a given design for specific test conditions. However, the results of such tests are usually difficult to extrapolate to other scenarios, making the performance demonstration protocols based only on experimental tests very costly and complex.

Modelling appears as a powerful tool to predict fire growth on composite structure at real scale. It reduces, but not totally, the need to conduct fire tests. It can also be used to further understand the physical processes that occur. But, the main advantage of this approach is the flexibility and the possibility of a rapid and cost-effective assessment of the fire performance in various scenarios compared to experimental approach. The challenge to modelling the fire behaviour of composite is the accurate analysis and representation of thermal, chemical, physical and failure processes, which control the thermal decomposition. Modelling underlies understanding and analysing all these processes as accurately as possible. It is further complicated because many processes are intertwined and are acting independently of one another. In addition, the numerical model needs to be fed by a large amount of input data on the thermophysical properties of each element constituting the simulated material in the temperature range of interest. These properties need to be quantified beforehand over the expected temperature range experimentally, which is not always easy.

The last 30 years have seen a surge of models being applied in simulations of fire behaviour on composite materials. Several researchers have developed different models to predict heat and mass transfers, decomposition, softening and failure of laminate4–26 or sandwich panels.27–33 However, the robustness of the state-of-the-art fire models is still stalled by a poor capability to model accurately the complex phenomena of the combustion and decomposition processes of solid fuel polymers and hypotheses used.

A common feature of many thermal modelling approaches is the decoupling of the fire from the composite. Therefore, the ignition and growth of fire are not considered in these analyses. Furthermore, the interaction between the solid and gas phases is not analysed. Instead, more models ignore the dynamics of the fire events and simply assume that the composite surface is uniformly heated under controlled heat flux (HF) or temperature conditions.

Most of the past studies have been performed mainly at small scale. Therefore, the ability of current fire modelling tools to properly predict fire development (e.g. flame spread and fire growth) on composite material is questionable. The phenomena are more complex at large scale.

Major progress was recently achieved to model the thermal decomposition and combustion of combustible structures by using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) fire models.4,16,18,24–26,32–38 CFD is used to analyse the flow dynamics and temperature of the flame over the composite surface. CFD-based fire modelling37 requires, however, an understanding of the processes occurring both in the solid phase and gas phase. This kind of model offers the possibility to consider complex geometries and ignition scenarios and evaluate the impact of design changes.

The general scope of the present work focuses on developing a methodology to take into account the fire contribution of composite walls and ceilings in the simulation of fires on board a ship. This work focuses in particular on modelling the fire behaviour of a glass fibre–reinforced polyester/balsa-cored sandwich material at several scales with the code Fire Dynamics Simulator (FDS) V 5.5.37 The approach adopted in this study uses the thick solid fuel pyrolysis model of the FDS to investigate fire propagation on walls integrating sandwich composite panels. Before modelling realistic large-scale fires, the ability of the FDS to simulate the fire behaviour of composite panels faithfully at several scales was evaluated. The methodology adopted in this study includes successive validation steps at increasing scales to better assess the final quality of numerical simulations of fire. It comprised three phases32–34: experiments on test rigs of increasing size, numerical simulations of these experiments with comparisons and feedback/corrective actions if needed. The process was iterative, a good match between experimental and numerical results on increasing scales validating the corresponding input data and the thermal decomposition model. The idea was to converge progressively towards a model adapted to reliable batch simulations of large-scale fires, for example, fires at scales closer to that of the end-use composite product.

This publication illustrates the above methodology by reporting experiments on a composite material at several scales. All the results at matter and material scales are detailed in another article.33 This reference focuses on defining comprehensive multi-step reaction pathways for both elements composing the sandwich at matter scale. These mechanisms were then used to solve an inverse problem with a mathematical model of the thermogravimetric (TG) experiments and to calculate the Arrhenius kinetic parameters. The methodology is based on a robust optimization technique that uses a genetic algorithm (GA), a research tool that uses the principle of Darwinian evolution to seek an optimal solution to a problem having a large number of adjustable parameters. Those parameters were then used as input data for the pyrolysis model introduced in the FDS. Test cases of increasing ‘complexity’ were performed to assess step by step the ability of the model(s) to reproduce the fire behaviour of each element constituting the sandwich structure.32,33 The numerical and experimental results for the studied sandwich material at small scale are then considered. In this study, results of the previous work obtained at matter and material scales33 are summarized and used as input data for further scales. Then in the second part, we use the set of data to evaluate the capacity of the FDS and its pyrolysis model to predict fire spread and fire growth on composite structures at intermediate scale up to large scale. The results of corresponding numerical simulations are presented and discussed.

sec.title: Tested materials
sec.p: The research was focused on a sandwich material made of two 3-mm-thick glass-reinforced polymer (GRP) laminate skins separated by a 40-mm-thick core material, leading to a total thickness of 46 ± 0.1 mm.

The 3-mm-thick inner and outer skins consisted of several layers of woven E fibreglass in an unsaturated polyester resin matrix without flame retardant. The fibre mass fraction is approximately 0.7. The density of the GRP laminate was 1945 kg·m−3. That of the resin is 1198 kg·m−3. The raw chemical formula of the resin, determined by the element analysis, may be written as C1H1.039O0.2.

The 40-mm-thick core is made of balsa wood (Ochroma pyramidale) blocks glued together to form a panel, with the balsa grain oriented perpendicular to the direction of the thickness of the composite plates. The nominal density of the balsa wood sheets as quoted by the manufacturer was 150 kg·m−3. However, the density of the wood was found rather non-homogeneous, varying typically from 80 to 220 kg·m−3 across the different balsa blocks glued together to form the core material. Chemically, the dry balsa is made up of carbon (45.8%), hydrogen (6.1%), oxygen (43.3%), small amounts of nitrogen (0.3%) and some inorganic elements.

sec.title: Matter-scale experiments (TG analyser)
sec.p: The so-called matter scale refers to samples weighing less than 10 mg and small enough to be assumed as a homogeneous and isotropic media.32,33 Investigations conducted at this scale provide information on chemical reactivity of a solid matter in temperature and chemical species. The results at matter scale are not presented in detail, but the complete set of results and discussions is provided in the study in Ref. 33

sec.title: Material-scale experiments
sec.p: This scale material corresponds to samples whose mass is between 10 and 500 g. Experiments are carried out with a cone calorimeter to determine the fire behaviour of the sandwich composite material.32,33 The results at material scale are not detailed here but are fully available in the study in Ref. 33.

sec.title: Semi-finished product–scale experiments
sec.p: This semi-finished product scale considers specimens whose mass ranges from 0.5 to 5 kg. The geometry and orientation of the tested product play an important role on fire growth. The measurements at this scale allow to study fire-spread mechanisms and heat transfer through products without considering the effects of fixations.32

sec.title: IMO lateral and ignition flame spread test
sec.p: The IMO lateral and ignition flame spread test (LIFT)38 was used as a screening test on samples at semi-finished product scale to study lateral fire spread on vertical panels. The 155 × 800-mm2 specimen was exposed to the heat released from a vertical air–gas fuelled radiant heat source inclined at 15° to the specimen. This angle allows exposing the test specimen surface to a continuously varying radiant exitance along its length. A piloted acetylene–air ignition source, which is part of this apparatus, was used to ignite the specimen during flame-spread tests. Effluents were collected and conducted through a specific hood, and then transported through a duct for analysis.

sec.title: Medium burning item
sec.p: The medium burning item (MBI) is a new test method for studying the reaction of materials to fire. It is defined in the standard ISO 21367.39 The tests are performed on a ‘medium–scale’ specimen to simulate the early development stage of a fire. The method is used as a screening test on an intermediate scale and to study the fire spread on a vertical panel.

The configuration consists of a vertical test specimen with a 0.7 × 0.5 m2 area exposed, at its lower part, to a constant radiant exitance from an electrical heater. The heat flux (HF) can be adjusted from 10 to 120 kW·m−2. A multiple-flame premixed line burner, positioned between the specimen and the heater, ignites flammable gases produced by the specimen. The effluents are collected and conducted by a fan through a specific hood and a duct equipped with measuring devices analogous to those on a cone calorimeter test rig; therefore, similar measurements and calculations can be done making possible systematic cross-checks with the results from cone calorimeter experiments.

sec.title: Finished product–scale experiments
sec.p: The finished products characterize specimens whose mass ranges from 5 to 50 kg. This case takes into account the effects of joints, mounting and fixing elements on material assemblies (as well as the behaviour of the tested assembly itself) that may have important feedback on the fire performance of products.32 The single burning item (SBI)40 is the test method used to access the reaction of finished products exposed to a 30-kW flame to fire (a sandbox burner supplied with propane). In the case, the dimensions of the test specimens were two wings of 1.0 × 1.5 m2 and 0.5 × 1.5 m2, respectively, assembled to form a corner. The test scenario was inspired from the standard ISO 9705 ‘Room corner test’ fire scenario,41 as the test scenario is related to a burner reproducing small pieces of upholstered furniture burnt in the corner of a room. The specimen is mounted on a trolley and positioned in a frame beneath an exhaust system. The specimen reaction is monitored. The effluents from the fire are collected in a hood and then transported through a duct for analysis. The heat release rates (HRRs; measured from oxygen depletion), lateral flame spread on the large wing of the test specimen and smoke production rate are measured.

sec.title: Large-scale experiments
sec.p: The tests on a reference room called ‘demonstrator’ made up of GRP/balsa-cored sandwich panels (bulkheads and decks) were performed to analyse the assembly conditions of the studied composite material, as shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Large-scale demonstrator made up of sandwich composite panels (bulkheads and decks).

sec.p: This room was considered large enough to representatively model the burning of a real construction. The fire source is an acetone pool fire placed in a corner, producing a stable HRR designed to produce by itself about the half of energy needed to lead to flashover. As this study was run on the field of defence, dimensions of the room are not presented here. This experiment was used to evaluate the capacity of the FDS code to simulate the fire growth and the occurrence of flashover within a composite structure, taking into account the presence of a ceiling. The aim was to later investigate the fire behaviour of the composite material studied in this project in real-scale fire scenarios.

sec.title: General considerations on fire simulation
sec.p: Numerical simulations were performed with the V 5.5 of the FDS code developed by the NIST Building and Fire Research Laboratory (Gaithersburg, Maryland, USA) and the VTT (Espoo, Finland). For further details on the FDS, the reader is directed to Ref. 37. The FDS solves an approximation of the Navier–Stokes equations appropriate for low-Mach number, thermally driven flows. The numerical algorithm employed is an explicit predictor/corrector scheme, with the second order accurate both in space and time, using a direct Poisson solver. The turbulence is treated using large eddy simulation (LES), via the classical Smagorinsky sub-grid scale model. A mixture fraction combustion model assuming a unique, infinitely fast global chemical reaction is used to estimate the heat release and smoke distributions in the computational domain. The radiation transport is treated using a finite volume solver in which grey gas absorption coefficient for soot and gas species is linked to the mixture fraction.

sec.title: Simplified pyrolysis model in the FDS37
sec.p: Heat transfer to solid walls is estimated by a one-dimensional (1D) solver on every wall cell with temperature-dependent wall thermal properties. It tracks the position of the pyrolysis front, a sharp demarcation between the virgin and char phases. These phases have different densities and may also have different thermophysical properties. The following form of the energy equation is solved

where ρ characterizes the density, c the specific heat capacity, T the temperature, t the time, x the space coordinate and k the thermal conductivity. The production between ΔHr (the change in enthalpy of reaction) and ω.ij (the rate of the reaction i and the species j) describes the heat production rate given by the pyrolysis model. The source term q.‴rad describes the in-depth radiative absorption and emission.

In this equation, the solid fuel is approximated as spectrally semi-transparent to thermal radiation, so that radiative absorption can occur in depth. The FDS uses several approaches to describe the devolatilization of solids. It depends largely on the availability of material properties and on the suitability of the underlying pyrolysis model. In our case, the reaction rate of a polymer that decomposes via a multi-stage reaction process is calculated using the Arrhenius kinetic rate equation of the pyrolysis front temperature Ts (determined by interpolation) (equation (2))

The decomposition process is described as follows: A is the pre-exponential factor, E is the activation energy, R is the gas constant, n is the reaction order, ρj is the density of the species j and ρs0 is the initial density of the material.
The mass loss rate (MLR) per unit volume is defined by
where Yr is the residual mass fraction of the reaction i and the species j.

The pyrolysis model of equation (2) does not contain a term of oxygen mass fraction. The mixture fraction combustion model used to compute the flame surface does not provide information about the oxygen concentration at the fuel surface of the reaction zone. It means that in the FDS, the heterogeneous oxidation reactions cannot be considered and all the decomposition reactions are thermolysis reaction. Thus, corrections must be introduced to the kinetic parameters calculated at the matter scale or to the decomposition mechanism. These corrections must force the FDS to calculate the correct MLR at a given temperature in order to produce the adequate quantity of gas fuel from the pyrolysis of the solid phase.

The fire test is modelled by applying a specific set of initial and boundary conditions that describe the initial state (T0), the convective environment and the applied external radiation level. Denoting T (0, t) as Ts, the initial and boundary conditions applied to equation (1) are give as follows
where ε is the emissivity, hcv is the convective heat transfer coefficient, Ts is the surface temperature, T∞ is the ambient temperature and σ is Stefan–Boltzmann constant and δ the thickness.
The assumptions inherent to the pyrolysis model, as applied in this work, include the following:

list-item.p: The in-depth generated volatiles are instantaneously transported to the surface;
The solid, liquid and gas/vapour phases are in local thermal equilibrium;
The condensation of gaseous products, the porosity effects and the shrinkage resulting from the reactions of bulk density change are negligible;
The total volume occupied by each element does not change because of the devolatilization;
There is no resistance to heat and mass transfer by the gases that are instantaneously released into the ambiance;
Materials are homogeneous and isotropic;
Average properties are calculated by appropriate mass or volume fraction weighting in conservation equation;
Heat transfer between the gas phase and the condensed phase inside the decomposing solid is negligible;
Surface regression is not accounted for, that is, the fuel thickness remains equal to its initial thickness regardless of the amount of solid fuel consumption;
Pyrolysis is assumed to occur at the fuel surface, that is, the pyrolysis rate is a function only of the surface temperature (it has been experimentally demonstrated that this is not).

sec.p: These assumptions can explain the deviation observed sometimes between experiments and numerical results. This point will be discussed further in this article.

sec.title: Required thermophysical properties
sec.p: In this study, the pyrolysis model is used to calculate the MLR and HRR histories as a function of the material properties. The solution of the thermal models required a large amount of empirical data on the thermal and decomposition properties of the composite. It can be seen from above that a comprehensible reaction pathway and material properties of each element j must be experimentally determined over a range of interest, to simulate the pyrolysis of a sandwich material: density (ρj), thermal conductivity (kj (T)), specific heat (cj(T)) and heat of reaction (ΔHr), effective heat of combustion (ΔHc), thermal emissivity (ε) and absorption coefficient (κ). In order to model a charring material, additional properties of intermediate decomposition product are needed.

Some of these elements could be estimated numerically. However, in this study, the number of optimized parameters was limited to the kinetic parameters. All the chemical and thermophysical properties were inferred from French reference test benches (see Table 1).

caption.p: Method to infer the thermophysical and radiative properties of our materials from French reference test benches. Temperature ranges are the measurement range applied on our materials

tr.td: ISO 22007-4: Laser flash44–46 (GRP laminate and polyester resin)
ISO 11357-3: Differential scanning calorimeters42,47 (virgin material and char)
ISO 1183-1: Pycnometry at 23°C +consideration of thermal expansion coefficient (a) for density correction52

sec.p: The scope of this measurement technique is very bounded. The problem is to measure combustible material properties when the decomposition process occurs. Indeed, beyond the thermal decomposition temperature, the thermal decomposition of these kinds of materials can lead to a molecular modification (charring or smelting) and a dimensional change (expansion) of the specimens, which affect the measurement. So far, it is difficult to measure thermal properties accurately, especially for transient species (tar, char, β-holocellulose, etc.). Actually, very few experimental facilities have been designed for the measurement of such data, especially for real materials such as low-density wood and thermoset polymers. Furthermore, no measurement technique is truly reliable. For this reason, the measurement cannot be carried out during the thermal decomposition but only on virgin material and char.

As this study was run on the field of defence, final thermophysical properties of the studied material could not be presented. However, Tables 2 and 3 give orders of magnitude of physical properties for similar elements, as available in the literature.

caption.p: Orders of magnitude of thermophysical properties and kinetic parameter for a similar sandwich structure from the literature, see Ref. 33 for details

fn.label: c
fn.p: The data are also available in temperature in this reference.

fn.label: d
fn.p: The Layer is composed of air and fibres.

caption.p: Kinetic parameter estimated under air from TG analyses for a similar sandwich structure. A two-step mechanism is given for the isophthalic polyester decomposition29 and three-stage reaction for the balsa wood50, see Ref. 33 for details

fn.label: a
fn.p: The kinetic parameters of balsa wood are defined for a heating rate of 8 K·min−1.

fn.label: b
fn.p: The kinetic parameters of isophthalic polyester resin are estimated for several heating rates: 2.5, 5, 10 and 20 K·min−1.

sec.p: The data were subsequently implemented in the FDS pyrolysis sub-model in order to carry out fire simulations of the sandwich structure.

sec.title: Model of thermal decomposition at the matter scale
sec.p: All results at the matter scale are detailed in Ref. 33. In this section, we summarize the results obtained at the matter scale. An ideal simulation of the thermal decomposition of sandwich structure on board a ship would require a comprehensible knowledge of all the reaction pathways involved in the decomposition of each element (polyester resin and balsa wood) composing the sandwich at matter scale. Indeed, the whole decomposition mechanism is one of the main input data for simulations as it allows specifying the mass balance of solids and gaseous products in our pyrolysis model.

The comprehensives and quantitative reaction pathway for each element (polyester resin and balsa wood) composing the sandwich were defined and validated from the experimental study of the MLR of condensed phases (TG), the kinetic of release of the main gases produced during thermal decomposition and the measurement of thermal properties. The TG investigations were carried out for various heating rates β (10, 20 and 50 K·min−1) and two atmospheres (pure nitrogen and air). Additional observations performed on the released gaseous compounds have led to defining mechanisms in accordance with the chemical process. The measurements in the gas releases were performed by using a Fourier transform infrared (FTIR).

The devolatilization of polyester matrix and balsa wood was defined in the form of a comprehensive multi-step reaction pathway with successive anaerobic thermolysis and oxidation reactions as shown in Tables 4 and 5.32,33 In these tables, the column ‘Reagents’ is the substance that is transformed during the reaction i. The column ‘Condensed phase’ corresponds to the condensed phase (liquid or solid) that remains in the sample holder at the end of a reaction. The gas effluents, listed in the column ‘Gas Product’, were associated with each reaction.

caption.p: Decomposition reaction of polyester resin considering species of solid and gas phases, from Ref. 33

tr.td: YR,3·Char . (1 −YR,3)·[CO2+ H2O + HCOH + CH4+ CO + NO + HCl +Yk]

fn.p: CO2: carbon dioxide; CO: carbon monoxide; H2O: water; NO: nitric oxide; HCl: hydrochloric acid; HCOH: formaldehyde; CH4: methane; C8H6O4: isophthalic acid; CH3CH2CHO: propionaldehyde; C8H8: styrene.

caption.p: Decomposition reaction of balsa wood considering species of solid and gas phases, from Ref. 33

fn.p: CO2: carbon dioxide; CO: carbon monoxide; H2O: water; CH3OH: methanol; HCOH: formaldehyde; CH4: methane; HCOOH: formic acid; CH3COOH: acetic acid.
Yk = CO2+ CO + H2O + HCOH; Yj = CH3OH + HCOOH.

sec.p: These mechanisms were then used to solve an inverse problem with a mathematical model of the TG experiments and to calculate the Arrhenius kinetic parameters. The methodology is based on a robust optimization technique that uses a GA, a research tool that uses the principle of Darwinian evolution to seek an optimal solution to a problem having a large number of adjustable parameters. Figure 2 presents the experimental and calculated prediction of the polyester resin thermal decomposition under nitrogen and air and for several heating rates (10, 20 and 50 K·min−1).33

caption.p: Solid phase processes of polyester resin during devolatilization for various heating rates β (10, 20 and 50 K·min−1) and two atmospheres (nitrogen and air): (a) plot results under nitrogen atmosphere and (b) plot results under air. [see Ref. 33 for details].

sec.p: The given data set makes it possible to describe the thermal decomposition of polyester resin whatever the atmosphere and the heating rate. It is seen that the reaction pathway captures the position, and the magnitude of the model peaks in each mass fraction curve, thus demonstrating the abilities of the reaction mechanism to predict the thermal decomposition of polyester resin in nitrogen at heating rate. The curve shapes and peak intensities are slightly underestimated at higher heating rates, especially in air. The phase shift between numerical and experimental results seems to be related to both the difficulty to reproduce the oxidation phenomena related to the kinetic of the reactions and to modifications of the tested specimen thermal behaviour during TG measurement. The solid phase might not be exactly in thermal equilibrium with the gas phase during measurements. The existence of a thermal gradient within the solid phase may explain the observed discrepancies in air regarding the temperature. Furthermore, an oxidization of the gas can affect the kinetics of the decomposition of the matter. Following the same approach, comprehensive reaction pathways of balsa wood and their associated kinetic parameters were estimated.32

sec.title: Simulation of fire behaviour at the material scale
sec.p: All the results at material scale are detailed in Ref. 33. In this section, we summarize the results obtained with cone calorimeter, when implementing these mechanisms, the kinetic parameters and the measured thermal properties of each element in the FDS. The fire behaviour of each individual layer (polyester resin, GRP composite and balsa wood) characterizing our composite and that of the sandwich material as a whole was simulated successively at material scale.33 The aim of the analyses at material scale was to determine the fire behaviour of GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite and evaluate the ability of the FDS to predict the solid–gas phase processes during devolatilization.

Before further study on the fire behaviour of sandwich structure, each element (polyester, polyester-laminate glass and balsa) was investigated separately. The tests revealed that the fire behaviour of sandwich structure depends largely on polyester resin amount infused and also on its fire reaction. Because of its insulation properties, balsa amplifies heat release and helps the ignition of the laminate skin. Besides, the core material does not contribute largely on the release of heat and smoke. In addition, the numerical simulations have shown the ability of the FDS code to predict the thermal degradation of the sandwich structure while highlighting some of the code weaknesses. Figure 3 presents the MLR and HRR obtained numerically, by using a unique set of input data, with corresponding experimental results for several irradiances with cone calorimeter (35, 50 and 75 kW·m−2).

caption.p: Comparison between the predictions (lines) of the model and the measurement (symbols) of the (a) heat release rate and (b) mass loss rate of the GRP sandwich composite for several radiant exitances of the heat source (35, 50 and 75 kW·m−2) from cone calorimeter [see ref. 33 for details].
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer.

sec.p: The approach reproduces the thermal decomposition and the fire behaviour of the sandwich structure rather correctly. The pyrolysis model is able to simulate the fire behaviour (energy, mass and species budgets) whatever the radiant exitance of the heat source (35, 50 and 75 kW·m−2), with a unique input data set.31 The differences between the experimental and numerical results are mainly related to the simplifying assumptions made in the FDS as presented in the section ‘Simplified pyrolysis model in the FDS’:

list-item.p: The simplicity of the pyrolysis model;
The impossibility to consider an oxygen term in the solid phase degradation;
The impossibility to separate the oxidation and anaerobic thermolysis reactions with a mixture fraction combustion model;
The inhomogeneous and anisotropic nature of the materials;
The non-adapted global reaction.

sec.p: The calculated MLRs are slightly lower than the experimental ones. For a radiant exitance of the heat source of 50 and 75 kW·m−2, the calculated MLR matches reasonably well with the experimental data. It can be noticed that the deviation increases at lower radiant HF. Furthermore, simulation leads to predict the sandwich ignition quicker. The discrepancy from the actual ignition time strongly decreases with increasing HF. The discrepancy can be related to thermal properties used,61 especially for transient species that are largely unknown and whose measurements are a difficult thing to do accurately. This discrepancy could be also related to the inability of a 1D model to capture 3D processes. Both flame and composites structures observed in the cone calorimeter experiments are clearly non-1D. The use of a 1D conductive heat transfer equation ignores heat conduction in the in-plane direction, overestimating the temperature. It should be highlighted that the heat diffusion in the in-plane direction is particularly important compared to thickness direction due to the thermal diffusivity characteristics of the fibre.7 In our case, that leads to an overestimation of the heating rate of the GRP laminate and to faster ignition. For anisotropic materials, such as composite material, a 3D thermal and pyrolysis model, as those proposed by Refs 6,9,10,16–18,21, may help achieve a better agreement. This remark is justified to predict in particular the flame spread at higher scale where irradiance gradients are important. By contrast, for isotropic polymer material, the use of 1D pyrolysis model seems reasonable to predict the outcome of cone calorimeter experiments.36

sec.title: Simulation at semi-finished product scale
sec.p: The flame-spread simulation is one of the most important issues in fire simulation. Before modelling the fire propagation on large scale or any more complex geometry, it is essential to check whether the pyrolysis model is able to provide reasonable prediction of lateral fire spread on a simple vertical sandwich composite panel.

sec.title: Prediction of the IMO LIFT test
sec.p: The simulation of this test bench was performed to assess the model ability to predict flame spread. In this regard, a 3D model of the LIFT geometry was created by using a Cartesian mesh.32 The dimensions of the numerical LIFT were specified according to the dimensions of the test bench38 as shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Numerical LIFT test with the computational fluid dynamics code Fire Dynamics Simulator.
LIFT: lateral and ignition flame spread test.

sec.p: In practice, Refs 37 and 62 recommend using a small mesh. Accordingly, a numerical grid size of 10 × 10 × 10 mm3 cells was chosen. Both the turbulent combustion of the gas phase and the pyrolysis of the solid fuel were numerically simulated. In the gas phase, the sub-grid scale turbulence was modelled by using the Smagorinsky model. In a LES computation, the convective boundary layer (CBL) is not directly resoled. The convection heat transfer to a surface is determined by how fast energy can diffuse from the free steam of a flow field through the boundary layer and into the surface. Therefore, the temperature gradient at the wall does not reflect the actual heat transfer that is occurring. A correlation is used to compute the heat transfer, which is called wall function.

As the initial condition, the gas in the computation domain was set still with ambient temperature. At the free side, static pressure boundary condition was employed. A radiant panel temperature was set to produce the desired HF at the sample surface. Several iterative simulations were performed to calibrate the irradiance over a dummy specimen as shown in Figure 5.

caption.p: Calibration of the desired irradiance level over a dummy specimen. The radiant panel temperature was set to produce the desired heat flux at the sample surface following the standard ISO 5658-2.38

sec.p: The ability of the CFD code to reproduce the HF and temperature observed experimentally at the surface of the specimen was studied deeper.32 The experimental uncertainties provided in Figure 5 have been estimated according to Ref. 63. The uncertainties correspond to two standard deviations (level of confidence 95%) and bench uncertainties. The previously estimated input data set after validation on material scale33 was used as input data without modification to simulate the LIFT test.

Following Janssens’64 approach, Figure 6(a) illustrates the transformed ignition time versus the incident radiant HF. The numerical ignition is reproduced at higher irradiances (>18 kW·m−2) with an acceptable deviation. Figure 6(b) shows again that the code overestimates the position of pyrolysis front at higher radiant HF. On these irradiance levels, flame spreading depends mainly on incident radiant HF of heat source. Moreover, Table 5 shows that the numerical thermal response parameter (TRP) is closed to the measurement in considering the uncertainty. This indicates that heating is well reproduced. So, the thermal properties used in this case seem to be appropriate to simulate flames spreading at high-enough HF.

caption.p: Comparison between numerical predictions (solid lines) and measurements (symbols) of (a) transformed ignition time following Janssens’ approach64 and (b) the front pyrolysis spread of GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite from the LIFT.
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer; LIFT: lateral and ignition flame spread test.

sec.p: Nevertheless, Figure 6(b) shows that the code underestimates flame spread when the radiant exitance of the heat source is less than 18 kW·m−2. This behaviour is entirely consistent with the results obtained by Kwon.65 For lower values of the HF, the opposed-flow to flame spread is controlled by the lateral conductive heat transfer in the solid phase. The deviation seems consistent because the code uses a 1D heat equation, which leads to poor representation of the thermal diffusion in the wall. This inability of the FDS to simulate lateral heat diffusion may explain the difficulties to reproduce the experimental critical flux at extinguishment (CFE) (Table 6). In addition, the definition of boundary conditions and the simplicity of the convective model may generate numerical deviations.

caption.p: Numerical and experimental CFE and TRP of GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite material from the LIFT

fn.p: CFE: critical flux at extinguishment; TRP: thermal response parameter; GRP: glass-reinforced polymer; LIFT: lateral and ignition flame spread test.

sec.p: It can be noticed that these vertical experimental configurations are within the limits of the FDS code. The correlations used to estimate the HF at the wall assume that the first cell includes totally the boundary layer. This assumption is not necessarily verified on this scale with the present mesh. The FDS exhibits great difficulties to simulate flame spread, especially in case of an opposed-flow to flame spread. Again, this difficulty seems to be related to a large extent to the use of a 1D heat equation. The following should also be considered:

list-item.p: (a) The mixture fraction model that does not take into account oxidization in flames;
(b) The radiation model that evaluates the heat produced by radiation through a global parameter χr constant for all flame regions;
(c) The simplicity of the convection model that does not simulate accurately the parietal exchanges at the walls.

sec.title: Prediction of the MBI
sec.p: The main interest of the MBI test is to assess the ability of the FDS to reproduce the fire growth on a vertical panel alone. In this regard, a 3D model of the MBI geometry was created by using a Cartesian mesh,32 as shown in Figure 7. The dimensions of the numerical MBI were specified according to the dimensions of the test bench.39

caption.p: Numerical MBI with the computational fluid dynamics code Fire Dynamics Simulator.
MBI: medium burning item.

sec.p: In order to provide proper and economical resolution for both the gas and solid phase computation, a local grid refinement is used. Cell sizes of 5 × 5 mm2 were used near to the heat source while 10 × 10 mm2 cells were used in the other part of the domain. A radiant panel temperature was set to produce the desired HF at the sample surface. As the initial condition, the gas in the computation domain was set still with ambient temperature. At the free side, static pressure boundary condition was employed. The volume flow rate of 95 L·s−1 was applied on the top of the domain.

For the first step, the ability of the FDS to reproduce the HF and temperature observed experimentally at the surface of the calcium silicate (CaSi) specimen was studied deeper.32 Analyses have showed that the simplicity of the modelling of convective flows does not allow an accurate prediction of the CBL close to the specimen. In the case of the MBI test, the convective exchanges are important, and the inability of the FDS to simulate the CBL may generate a source of errors on the fire spread.

For the second step, the input data set defined at material scale and validate at material scale33 was directly used without modifications to predict the fire growth from the MBI test. For instance, Figure 8 provides a comparison between the numerical and experimental MLR and HRR for an irradiance level of 50 kW·m−2. The experimental uncertainties provided in Figure 8 have been estimated according to Ref. 63. Uncertainties correspond to two standard deviations (level of confidence 95%) and bench uncertainties.

caption.p: Comparison between numerical predictions (solid lines) and measurements (symbols) of (a) the mass loss rate and (b) the heat release rate of the GRP sandwich composite from the MBI test.
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer; MBI: medium burning item.

sec.p: These graphs highlight some model weaknesses to predict the fire growth on a sandwich composite alone. Despite what precedes, numerical results reveal that the model satisfactorily reproduces the main qualitative trends observed experimentally up to 400 s. During this period, the upward fire spread is dominant and mainly depend on the radiative exchanges in gas phase. The radiative model used in the FDS is able to reproduce the radiative heat transfer and the thermal balance at the surface of our sandwich. The experimental propagation of pyrolysis zone was studied and compared with the model.33 From 400 s onward, Figure 8 shows significant deviations between the experiment shape of HRR and MLR and the model. During this period, the pyrolysis area grows laterally. To assess the extent of the fire spread on the specimen surface, Figure 9 compares the experimental and numerical pyrolyzed area at the end of the test.

caption.p: Comparison between numerical predictions and measurements of pyrolyzed area on the GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite from the MBI test.
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer; MBI: medium burning item.

sec.p: This analysis reveals difficulties of the model to accurately reproduce the opposed-flow to flame spread, such as the lateral and down fire spread over the specimen surface. Figure 9 shows that the active pyrolysis area observed experimentally is larger than the one obtained numerically. The experimental pyrolyzed area is about 0.23 m2, while the calculated pyrolyzed area is 0.168 m2. Several factors may explain these differences:

list-item.p: The use of a 1D heat transfer equation. As previously seen, this is not suitable to predict the opposed-flow to flame spread, which is dependent on the lateral heat diffusion through the condensed phase. Therefore, the prediction of the opposed-flow to flame spread actually requires a 2D or 3D equation to solve this problem.

The model of convective exchange near to the panel that is too elementary. The boundary layer is not fully resolved, and the flow at the first near wall node is not dominated by the viscous effect. Actually, the code used a wall function, which does not use a fine resolution of the boundary layer. The correlations used to estimate the temperature to the walls assume that the first mesh includes boundary layer, which is not necessarily well tested with our mesh size. It is unfortunately difficult to circumvent this problem here since the combustion occurs precisely within the boundary layer. It should be clear that a refinement of the boundary layer would be necessary in the future. For instance, it could be interesting to use detached eddy simulation (DES) approach in the future.

The choice of the discretization, which can strongly affect the prediction. Indeed, the Smagorinsky turbulence model used by the FDS suggests that the diffusion of sub-grid is proportional to the mesh size. A too coarse mesh combines a strong diffusion that can affect the calculation of temperature gradient. However, the too thin mesh does not always give the best results for the same reasons. The diffusion of sub-grid iterates indirectly more or less the actual phenomena of mixing at small scales. In fact, it seems that the mesh size used led to increased buoyancy forces on the vertical walls. The temperature field near to the panel is thereby changed.

sec.p: Therefore, the test bench is within the limit of the numerical simulation. The model used to estimate the HF near to the walls assumes that the first mesh includes boundary layer, which is not necessarily well tested with our mesh. It is unfortunately difficult to circumvent this problem, since combustion takes place precisely within the boundary layer.

sec.title: Simulation at finished product scale
sec.p: The analysis at finished product scale were used to validate and check the quality of simulations regarding fire spreading over material plate assemblies from the SBI. In this regard, a 3D model of the SBI geometry was created according to the dimensions of the test bench.40 An uniform grid was chosen with cell dimensions of 2 cm on each side as a result of a compromise between flow resolution and computational time. As the boundary condition, the gas in the computation domain was set still with ambient temperature. At the free side, static pressure boundary condition was employed. The volume flow rate of 60 m3·s−1 at 20°C was applied on the top of the domain. The SBI test was modelled considering that the material was exposed to a propane diffusion flame as shown in Figure 10.

caption.p: Numerical SBI with the computational fluid dynamics code Fire Dynamics Simulator.
SBI: single burning item.

sec.p: The propane diffusion burner produces a 30.7 kW HRR. The ability of the CFD code to reproduce the flame height, the HF and temperature observed experimentally at the surface of the specimen was studied deeper.32

Figure 11 compares the HRR obtained numerically with the corresponding experimental HRR, while Figure 12 presents the position of the end pyrolysis front on the greater wing of the sandwich composite assembly obtained numerically with the corresponding experimental results. The model correctly reproduces the main trends observed experimentally regarding the fire development on the tested multi-layered material. Figure 11 explains that the HRR is correctly reproduced with, however, a steeper slope, correlated with a faster fire expansion. These results are in good agreement with the observations of Lautenberger et al.35 and Hietaniemi et al.66 This behaviour may be due to the fact that fire mainly spreads upwards during its development phase. The phenomenon strongly depends on convective movements at the walls and around, and the radiative input from the surrounding flames, while the contribution of conduction in the solid and gas phases is insignificant.32 From 600 s onwards (see Figure 11), the intrinsic properties of the sandwich composite lead to a significant lateral expansion of pyrolysis. The conductive heat transfer in the solid phase prevails during fire spread. Thus, the deviation observed (Figure 3) seems to be related to a large extent to the use of a 1D heat equation, which is thus not appropriate to simulate lateral fire spreading (Figure 12) at low irradiance levels. It can be concluded that, unfortunately, a 1D heat transfer equation for the polymeric material is not adapted to simulate the lateral propagation of materials with high-flame-spread characteristics. Thus, the same remarks made in the case of the LIFT and MBI tests apply here as well. To model the heat transfer into the composite, 2D or 3D systems are required.

caption.p: Comparison between numerical predictions (solid lines) and measurement (symbols) of heat release rate GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite from the SBI test.
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer; SBI: single burning item.
Comparison between numerical predictions and measurements of the pyrolyzed area on the greater wing (panel of 1500 × 1000 mm2) of the GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite from the SBI test.
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer; SBI: single burning item.

sec.title: Large-scale simulation
sec.p: Large-scale simulations refer to validation simulations of situations on the scale of a so-called ‘demonstrator’ made up of GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite panels (bulkheads and decks). This last step was used to evaluate the FDS code capacities and mainly the pyrolysis model to simulate fire growth inside a composite structure, taking into accounts the presence of a ceiling and the convective transfer. The aim was to later investigate the fire behaviour of the same composite material in real-scale fire scenarios, some leading to flashover.

In this regard, the demonstrator mesh was defined from the actual dimensions (Figure 1) of the experimental test facility. The grid is uniform, and the cell dimensions are 5 cm on each side as a result of a compromise between flow resolution and computational time. As the boundary condition, the gas in the computation domain was set still with ambient temperature. At the free side, static pressure boundary condition was employed. The fire source is an acetone pool fire placed in a corner of the room. As this study was run on the field of defence, dimensions of the room and fire source are not presented here.

Figure 13 presents the numerical prediction of fire growth in the demonstrator with the corresponding experimental results. The fire growth is well predicted by the FDS up to the flashover in a room with GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite walls. These large-scale simulation results seem to confirm the relevance of the decomposition models obtained from TG–FTIR to accurately predict each step of a fire growth and the flashover occurrence in a room with composite walls under well-ventilated conditions. To confirm these observations, Figure 14 compares the normalized MLR m.* obtained numerically with the corresponding experimental one. For confidential reasons, the results are normalized.

caption.p: Comparison between experimental results ((a) to (c)) and numerical predictions ((d) to (f)) of fire growth up to the flashover in a room with GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite walls. Experimental results at (a) t* = 0.23, (b) t* = 0.36 and (c) t* = 0.40 (flashover). Numerical results at (d) t* = 0.23, (e) t* = 0.36 and at (f) t* = 0.40 (flashover). Parts (d) to (f) show the heat release rate per unit volume (200 kW·m−3) and the smoke related to the polyester combustion.
Comparison between the predictions (solid lines) of model and the measurement (symbols) of normalized mass loss rate in a room with a GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite walls.
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer.

sec.p: During the growth phase (t* < 0.4), the FDS results match the experimental data reasonably well up to the flashover. The code predicts accurately the evolution of MLR. Although the use of a 1D heat equation shows limits to predict lateral spread, this equation seems appropriate to predict fire development under local, well-ventilated conditions, where radiative conditions are different. Indeed, fire spreads mainly upwards before being amplified by the ceiling.

During the post-flashover period (t* > 0.4), Figure 14 reveals difficulties to simulate the experimental MLR. There is a large difference between the experimental and numerical kinetics of devolatilization. This deviation may partly come from the quality of the mass loss measurement.32 However, the experimental accuracy cannot completely explain this discrepancy. The FDS simulation also tends to overestimate the amount of gaseous fuel in reaction. During the post-flashover period, there is a lack of oxygen in the local condition, and then the environment becomes under-ventilated in some places where anaerobic thermolysis occurs. The oxidation of gaseous fuel at the door and outside the room is observed. However, extinction cannot be reproduced correctly with the current CFD code. To overcome this problem, the FDS includes a simple flame extinction model that interacts only in the gas phase and not on the solid phase. This point cannot be addressed in the current CFD code because the reaction rate does not induce the oxygen term due to the use of a mixture fraction combustion model. The FDS indicates that the degradation process of the sandwich composite and the decomposition kinetics are not changed in the room during oxygen depletion. The sandwich composite is decomposed by the same multi-oxidative reaction mechanism, although oxygen is lacking; the numerical degradation kinetics being only controlled by the local temperature.

Figure 14 shows the normalized temperature on ceiling level. This figure also reports the mean temperature over the ceiling level. These numerical and experimental values correspond to an average temperature of over 12 thermocouples distributed uniformly at the ceiling. The numerical simulation used virtual thermocouples placed at the same locations as in the experiments.

The temperature estimates on ceiling level (Figure 15) are in good agreement with measurements. This result allows us to validate the capability of the FDS to simulate the gas phase phenomena occurring in an enclosure fire during the phase of fully developed fire. Furthermore, this result shows that the deviation observed in the MLR (Figure 14) is not related to an overestimation of the room temperature. This demonstrates again that the problem is related to the pyrolysis of materials.

caption.p: Comparison between numerical predictions (solid lines) and measurements (symbols) of normalized average temperature at the ceiling level in a room with a GRP/balsa-cored sandwich composite walls.
GRP: glass-reinforced polymer.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In order to accurately simulate the fire behaviour of a composite material during fire scenario simulations, a methodology was adopted: calibration of the chemical and thermophysical intrinsic properties of the considered material from small-scale experiments and validation of a numerical model by comparison of simulations with fire test results on medium and large scales. The software program selected here to model the fire behaviour of composite structures is the FDS V 5.5 with a pyrolysis model.

This article has shown abilities of the FDS to predict the devolatilization processes of a GRP/balsa-cored sandwich while highlighting some of its weaknesses. The large-scale simulation results seem to confirm the relevance of using decomposition models derived obtained from TG measurements (matter scale) to accurately predict the flashover occurrence in a room with composite walls (large scale). During the post-flashover period, the code, even if it overestimates the experimental MLR, remains largely safe. Given the application of this work, this result is quite acceptable for FSE approach in comparable geometries.

From these assumptions, the global model of the sandwich is able to predict the energy, mass and species budgets measured experimentally, whatever the irradiance level if not too low. The correct modelling of the thermal decomposition was, however, limited mainly by the use of 1D heat equation and the inability of the code to simulate oxidation reactions. The other limiting assumptions are less restrictive. In this regard, improvements could be brought to the FDS and CFD codes in the future by using a 3D heat equation and taking into account a term of oxygen in the pyrolysis process. This means leaving the current combustion model based on mixture fraction to switch to a more sophisticated approach, where oxygen could diffuse to the surface of solid fuels, even under flames.

More specifically, the present work has highlighted the difficulties of the code to correctly predict lateral fire spread on a vertical panel, in particular in the presence of an upstream flow with respect to the direction of the flame spread. These results are related first to the use of a 1D heat equation for the solid phase and the simplicity of the convection model that does not simulate wall transfers accurately. In the future, this subject must be a significant improvement of the FDS.

A correct modelling of the flame extinction also appears to be a relevant claim for simulating the fire development in a room with a combustible structure, where the fire is controlled by the airflow.

Finally, it appears from this study that using the FDS code, in its current version, is reasonable for numerical studies of fire scenarios on board a ship. The present results are very promising as they show that it is already possible to use an approach per calculated pyrolysis to predict the occurrence of a flashover in a well-ventilated compartment of ships. Following this study, several fire scenarios are being studied. The study of an under-ventilated fire, however, still requires to include additional improvements to the code.

d Pore diameter, m

m Mass, kg

m
.
Mass loss rate, kg·s−1

m
.

Normalized mass loss rate, s−1

n Exponent, (–)

q
.
Flux, W

Q
.
Heat release rate, W

sec.p:
ω
.
Reaction rate, s−1

φ Generic variable, (–)

sec.title: Subscripts
sec.p: ∞ Ambient
g Gasification
i Reaction species i
j Condensed phase species j
0 initial
O2 Dioxygen
p Pyrolysis
r Reaction
R Residue
rad Radiation
s Surface
v Virgin condensed phase

sec.p: . Per unit time
′ Per unit area

¯
Weighted or averaged

ack.p: This work was carried out within the framework of the EMC2 MP08 project ‘Fire performance of composites for shipbuilding’. All the MP08 partners (Bénéteau, Bureau Veritas, DCNS, Ecole des Mines de Nantes, ISMANS, SAITEC and STX Europe) are gratefully acknowledged for their fruitful collaboration. The authors also thank Carine Chivas Joly.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This study received financial support from the Pays de la Loire Region and the French government (Direction Générale de la Compétitivité, de l’Industrie et des Services, Direction Générale de l’Armement).

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Dr Damien Marquis received PhD (2010) degree in Heat tranfer, Energy and Combustion from the Ecole de Mines de Nantes (France). He is currently a scientist in the Energy, Environment & Combustion Division at Laboratoire national de métrologie et d’essais (LNE), the French national laboratory for testing and metrology. His major reseach interests include experimental and numerical investigation of fire-related phenomena, heat transfer problem, thermophysics properties measurements, reactivity and flammability of polymeric materials, fire toxicity and under-ventilated fire phenomena.

Prof Michel Pavageau received PhD (1994) degree in Fluid and Turbulent Transfer Dynamics at Ecole Centrale de Nantes, France. He then spent 2.5 years at the Meteorologisches Institut of Hamburg University, working on wind tunnel simulations of car-exhaust pollution dispersion in street canyons. He left Hamburg in 1996 to join Ecole des Mines de Nantes. His work at Ecole des Mines de Nantes has addressed VOC dispersion in the atmosphere, plane impinging plane jets with a focus on the aerodynamic instabilities that develop at the wall in the impingement region and their effects with respect to heat and mass transfers in this flow region, application or air curtains to the design of heat confining systems (fire safety systems, processes for the food industry, etc.), fire propagation on composite materials. He is a regular reviewer in several international journals in fluid dynamics and heat transfers. Michel Pavageau is the holder of a HDR (accreditation to direct research – the highest degree in the French University system) since 2006. He is currently full Professor at Ecole des Mines d’Albi-Carmaux, heading the International Relations office of the school since 2010.

Eric Guillaume works in fire sciences since 1998. He famerly lead the fire behaviour department of French Railway, than changed company in 2005. Nowaday, he works for LNE, as head of research for whole testing activities. He is a fire expert involved in various missions, including teaching, standardization and regulation, fire toxicity and modelling fire behaviour of materials. He is also convenor of the standardization group ISO TC92/SC3/WGA, concerning fire models for toxicity testing.
